byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Al Baker, J. David Goodman, Mireya Navarro and Eli Rosenberg, and research by Susan C. Beachy.
byline.original: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr., BENJAMIN MUELLER and NATE SCHWEBER

abstract: Tyrone Howard, suspect in murder of Officer Randolph Holder, was given series of second chances by justice system during two decades of criminal activity; drug rivals Howard had run afoul of, however, pursued him for years, fueling gang feud that led to shootout that claimed Holder.
lead_paragraph: The man arrested in the fatal shooting of Randolph Holder, a New York City police officer, received a series of breaks in nearly two decades of frequent arrests and convictions.

headline.main: Tyrone Howard, Suspect in Officer’s Killing, Had String of Second Chances
headline.print_headline: Second Chances Kept Coming for Suspect in Officer’s Death

snippet: The man arrested in the fatal shooting of Randolph Holder, a New York City police officer, received a series of breaks in nearly two decades of frequent arrests and convictions.
